intro: Teesdalia nudicaulis, commonly known as the naked-stemmed sunflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and opposite leaf arrangement. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun, often found in desert or semi-arid environments. Its slender, hairless stems and yellow-orange flower heads make it easily identifiable. It is also known for its ability to attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
